awd_titl_txt: Applications of Microlocal Sheaves of Spectra and K-Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project concerns algebraic topology and symplectic geometry.  Algebraic topology is the theory of those properties of space that are unchanged by large continuous deformations; for example, the property of having a hole.  Algebraic topologists organize their subject using number systems called ring spectra or extraordinary homology theory.  Symplectic geometry is a mathematical formalism for classical mechanics.  Many questions in symplectic geometry have been resolved through use of a tool called Lagrangian Floer theory.  This project aims to develop a single tool that generalizes both theories, forging new connections between the subjects.

Floer homotopy theory is an emerging refinement of Floer homology.  It bears the same relationship to Floer homology that extraordinary homology bears to ordinary homology.  Ultimately it should attach a category, enriched in spectra, to a symplectic manifold.  This project aims to construct this category using the microlocal theory of sheaves, to give new techniques for computing it, to use it to prove some conjectures about the algebraic topology of symplectic manifolds, and conversely to symplectically illuminate some aspects of the category of spectra.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
During the grant period, the PI and his coauthors wrote and posted four papers addressing the interactions of sheaf theory, homotopy theory, and symplectic geometry. He began a new project which is in progress.

With Johnson-Freyd, motivated by new "moonshine" conjectures that emerged in the 2010s, the PI wrote a paper computing the third homologies of many of the sporadic finite groups. The paper appeared in SIGMA.

With Williams and Zaslow, the PI wrote a paper relating mirror symmetry for toric surfaces to the dimer model. This paper appeared in Selecta Math.

The PI wrote a paper formulating some conjectures on the K-theory of Fukaya categories, and proving them in special cases. This paper was posted to the arXiv.

With Lekili, the PI wrote a paper explaining a modification of a standard construction of mirror symmetry, whose output is the Fargues-Fontaine curve. This paper appeared in Forum of Math Sigma.

With Yuan and Feng, the PI began to study stable-homotopy-theoretic versions of Broue's conjecture. He produced new equivalences between blocks of categories of G-spectra, for different finite groups G. This paper is being written.

These results were presented in seminars, conferences, and colloquia, some in person and some online.

The PI's student Melissa Zhang defended her PhD on localization in Khovanov homology. The PI began working with a new PhD student, Jee Uhn Kim.


Last Modified: 03/24/2022
Modified by: David Treumann
